OK Computer

A groundbreaking album that defined a generation. OK Computer marks a significant departure from The Bends, and takes Radiohead into more experimental territory. The album's themes of alienation, technological anxiety, and societal disconnection proved remarkably prescient.

Thom Yorke's haunting vocals float over intricate instrumentation, creating a soundscape that feels both personal and universal. From the driving pulse of "Paranoid Android" to the ethereal beauty of "Exit Music (For a Film)," each track contributes to a cohesive artistic statement.

The innovative production techniques pioneered by the band and producer Nigel Godrich would go on to influence countless artists across genres. OK Computer remains a masterpiece that grows more relevant with each passing year.

Paranoid Android

The multi-part suite showcases the band's ambition with its shifting time signatures and moods. Equal parts menacing and beautiful.

Karma Police

One of the album's most accessible moments that manages to balance pop sensibilities with experimental tendencies.

No Surprises

A deceptively gentle lullaby with devastating lyrics that perfectly captures the album's themes of quiet desperation.
